Iberostar Quetzal & Tucan: Complete Resort Guide

Where Wildlife Roams the Grounds

Last updated: January 2025

Iberostar Quetzal and its sister property Tucan put Iberostar on the Riviera Maya map back in 1998. What made them famous wasn't just Caribbean beach access—it was the wildlife. Peacocks strut across the paths. Coatis (raccoon relatives) appear at breakfast. Iguanas bask everywhere. The Mayan-inspired architecture has aged beautifully amid mature jungle landscaping. These aren't the flashiest or newest Iberostar properties, but they've developed character that new resorts can't manufacture.

In This Guide

  • Overview & Vibe
  • The Wildlife Experience
  • Accommodations
  • Dining
  • Beach & Pools
  • Mayan Architecture

Overview & Vibe

{<strong>The Original Iberostar Riviera Maya:</strong></p><p>Quetzal and Tucan were Iberostar's pioneering properties in the region. While the chain has expanded to the massive Paraíso complex, these originals retain devoted followings.</p><p><strong>The Sister Property Concept:</strong></p><ul><li>Quetzal and Tucan sit side by side</p><ul><li>Guests at either access both properties</p><ul><li>Shared beach and some facilities</p><ul><li>Different room configurations</p><ul><li>Book whichever has availability</p><p><strong>Key Stats (Combined):</strong></p><ul><li>350 rooms at Quetzal</p><ul><li>350 rooms at Tucan</p><ul><li>Shared Caribbean beachfront</p><ul><li>10+ restaurants across both</p><ul><li>Wildlife throughout grounds</p><ul><li>Established 1998</p><p><strong>The Vibe:</strong></p><ul><li>Natural and eco-focused</p><ul><li>Wildlife encounters daily</p><ul><li>Mayan architectural elements</p><ul><li>European vacation culture</p><ul><li>Family-friendly throughout</p><ul><li>Mature, established grounds</p><p><strong>Who Stays Here:</strong></p><ul><li>Nature lovers</p><ul><li>Families with children</p><ul><li>Iberostar loyalists</p><ul><li>European travelers</p><ul><li>Those who appreciate established properties</p><ul><li>Wildlife enthusiasts}

The Wildlife Experience

{<strong>Animals on Property:</strong></p><p>This is what makes Quetzal/Tucan special. The properties were built to coexist with local wildlife, and animals roam freely.</p><p><strong>What You'll See:</strong></p><p><strong>Peacocks</strong> They're everywhere—strutting paths, displaying feathers, becoming part of the resort identity. Kids love them.</p><p><strong>Coatis (Coatimundis)</strong> Raccoon-like mammals that appear hoping for scraps. Cute but don't feed them (seriously, they can bite).</p><p><strong>Iguanas</strong> Bask on rocks, paths, and near pools. Harmless and photogenic.</p><p><strong>Tropical Birds</strong> Parrots, toucans (the resort's namesake), and various exotic species in the jungle canopy.</p><p><strong>Wildlife Guidelines:</strong></p><ul><li>Don't feed animals (posted everywhere)</p><ul><li>Respect their space</p><ul><li>Photos encouraged</p><ul><li>Some areas have more activity</p><ul><li>Morning and evening best for sightings</p><p><strong>Why This Matters:</strong> The wildlife creates an experience unavailable at newer, more developed resorts. Children especially love the animal encounters that happen just walking to breakfast.}

Accommodations

{<strong>Room Categories (Both Properties):</strong></p><p><strong>Standard Room (from $300/night)</strong></p><ul><li>344 sq ft</p><ul><li>Garden or pool views</p><ul><li>King or two double beds</p><ul><li>Basic but comfortable</p><ul><li>Recently refreshed</p><p><strong>Superior Room ($350-420)</strong></p><ul><li>Same size, better location</p><ul><li>Closer to beach or amenities</p><ul><li>Preferred buildings</p><p><strong>Junior Suite ($420-520)</strong></p><ul><li>490 sq ft</p><ul><li>Living area</p><ul><li>Better for families</p><ul><li>Enhanced amenities</p><p><strong>Suite ($550-700)</strong></p><ul><li>630+ sq ft</p><ul><li>Separate living room</p><ul><li>Premium location</p><ul><li>Best accommodations available</p><p><strong>Star Prestige (Limited Availability):</strong></p><ul><li>Enhanced category</p><ul><li>Exclusive lounge</p><ul><li>Premium spirits</p><ul><li>Priority services</p><p><strong>Quetzal vs. Tucan:</strong> Very similar—choose based on availability. Tucan tends to be marginally quieter; Quetzal marginally closer to some facilities. Either works.}

Dining

{<strong>10+ Restaurants Across Both Properties:</strong></p><p><strong>At Quetzal:</strong></p><p><strong>La Cava (International Fine Dining)</strong> The premium dinner option with international cuisine and wine cellar.</p><ul><li>Dinner only</p><ul><li>Reservations recommended</p><p><strong>Sakura (Japanese)</strong> Sushi and teppanyaki in atmospheric setting.</p><ul><li>Dinner only</p><p><strong>La Hacienda (Mexican)</strong> Traditional Mexican in hacienda-themed space.</p><ul><li>Dinner only</p><p><strong>Main Buffet</strong> All-day dining with international and Mexican stations.</p><ul><li>All meals</p><p><strong>At Tucan (Accessible to All):</strong></p><p><strong>La Dolce Vita (Italian)</strong> Pastas, pizzas, Italian wines.</p><ul><li>Dinner only</p><p><strong>El Gaucho (Steakhouse)</strong> Grilled meats, South American style.</p><ul><li>Dinner only</p><p><strong>Additional buffet and casual options</strong></p><p><strong>Cross-Property Dining:</strong> Guests at either property can dine at any restaurant across both. This effectively doubles your dining options.}

Beach & Pools

{<strong>Shared Caribbean Beachfront:</strong></p><p>Quetzal and Tucan share beach access—a beautiful stretch of Riviera Maya Caribbean.</p><p><strong>Beach Features:</strong></p><ul><li>White sand beach</p><ul><li>Calm Caribbean water (usually)</p><ul><li>Full lounger and umbrella service</p><ul><li>Beach bars and food service</p><ul><li>Water sports available</p><ul><li>Seaweed management (varies by season)</p><p><strong>Pools:</strong></p><p>Each property has multiple pools:</p><p><strong>Main Pool Areas</strong></p><ul><li>Large pools with swim-up bars</p><ul><li>Activity programming</p><ul><li>Family-friendly</p><ul><li>Full service</p><p><strong>Quieter Pools</strong></p><ul><li>Less activity</p><ul><li>Smaller, more peaceful</p><ul><li>Good for adults seeking calm</p><p><strong>Kids' Pool Areas</strong></p><ul><li>Shallow depths</p><ul><li>Splash features</p><ul><li>Near kids' club</p><p><strong>Water Sports Included:</strong></p><ul><li>Kayaking</p><ul><li>Paddle boarding</p><ul><li>Snorkeling equipment</p><ul><li>Sailing (small craft)}

Mayan Architecture

{<strong>Design That Ages Beautifully:</strong></p><p>The properties were built with Mayan-inspired architecture that has only improved with time as jungle has grown around structures.</p><p><strong>Architectural Elements:</strong></p><ul><li>Pyramid-influenced rooflines</p><ul><li>Natural materials (stone, wood)</p><ul><li>Thatched palapas</p><ul><li>Open-air common areas</p><ul><li>Integration with jungle</p><ul><li>Water features throughout</p><p><strong>The 25-Year Advantage:</strong></p><ul><li>Mature palms and tropical plants</p><ul><li>Established jungle canopy</p><ul><li>Wildlife habitat developed</p><ul><li>Soft, natural atmosphere</p><ul><li>Character impossible to manufacture</p><p><strong>Contrast with New Resorts:</strong> New properties have pristine facilities but young landscaping. Quetzal/Tucan's mature grounds create an atmosphere that takes decades to develop.}

Practical Information

{<strong>Getting There:</strong></p><ul><li>Cancún Airport (CUN): 50-55 minutes</p><ul><li>Private transfer: ~$80 each way</p><ul><li>Near Playa del Carmen (15 minutes)</p><ul><li>Part of Playacar area</p><p><strong>What's Included:</strong></p><ul><li>All meals (10+ restaurants)</p><ul><li>Drinks including premium options</p><ul><li>Access to both properties</p><ul><li>Kids' club</p><ul><li>Non-motorized water sports</p><ul><li>Entertainment</p><ul><li>WiFi</p><ul><li>Gratuities</p><p><strong>What Costs Extra:</strong></p><ul><li>Spa treatments</p><ul><li>Excursions</p><ul><li>Golf (nearby Iberostar course)</p><ul><li>Motorized water sports</p><ul><li>Star Prestige upgrades</p><p><strong>Best Time to Visit:</strong></p><ul><li>Year-round viable</p><ul><li>Peak: December-April</p><ul><li>Value: May-June, November</p><ul><li>Wildlife: Always present}

Pros & Cons

{<strong>Why Choose Iberostar Quetzal/Tucan:</strong></p><p>✅ <strong>Pros:</strong></p><ul><li>Unique wildlife experience</p><ul><li>Mature, beautiful grounds</p><ul><li>Mayan-inspired architecture</p><ul><li>Access to sister property</p><ul><li>European vacation culture</p><ul><li>Established and reliable</p><ul><li>Good value for quality</p><ul><li>Near Playa del Carmen</p><ul><li>Family-friendly throughout</p><ul><li>Character new resorts lack</p><p>❌ <strong>Cons:</strong></p><ul><li>Not the newest facilities</p><ul><li>Some areas showing age</p><ul><li>Not luxury tier</p><ul><li>Large properties (lots of walking)</p><ul><li>Wildlife can be nuisance (coatis)</p><ul><li>Seaweed possible</p><ul><li>European crowds at times</p><ul><li>Not adults-only option</p><ul><li>Paraíso complex is newer</p><p><strong>Compared to Alternatives:</strong></p><ul><li>vs. Iberostar Paraíso: Paraíso newer, bigger; Quetzal/Tucan more character</p><ul><li>vs. Dreams: Dreams more polished; Quetzal/Tucan more natural</p><ul><li>vs. Barceló: Similar tier; Iberostar has wildlife advantage</p><ul><li>vs. Grand Palladium: GP larger; Iberostar more manageable}

Booking Tips

{<strong>How to Book:</strong></p><p><strong>Best Approaches:</strong></p><ol><li>Compare Quetzal vs. Tucan rates</p><ol><li>Costco Travel for packages</p><ol><li>Direct Iberostar for loyalty perks</p><ol><li>Either property works—choose by price</p><p><strong>Quetzal vs. Tucan Decision:</strong></p><ul><li>Very similar experience</p><ul><li>Price difference usually minimal</p><ul><li>Both access same beach and facilities</p><ul><li>Tucan slightly quieter</p><ul><li>Quetzal slightly more central</p><ul><li>Don't stress the choice</p><p><strong>Room Selection:</strong></p><ul><li>Near beach = shorter walk</p><ul><li>Higher floors = better views</p><ul><li>Away from main areas = quieter</p><ul><li>Request recently renovated</p><p><strong>Wildlife Maximizing:</strong></p><ul><li>Morning walks for most activity</p><ul><li>Areas near jungle edges</p><ul><li>Don't feed animals (really)</p><ul><li>Camera ready always</p><p><strong>Best Value Timing:</strong></p><ul><li>May-June: Good rates</p><ul><li>September-October: Cheapest (hurricane risk)</p><ul><li>Book 2-3 months ahead</p><ul><li>Watch for Iberostar promotions}

Frequently Asked Questions

Can I really see peacocks and wildlife just walking around?

Yes—the wildlife is real and present daily. Peacocks are everywhere, coatis appear at meals, iguanas bask on paths, and birds fill the canopy. It's not a zoo; they roam freely. Many guests consider this the resort's best feature.

Should I book Quetzal or Tucan?

Either works—the differences are minimal. You access both properties regardless of where you book. Choose based on price or availability. Tucan is marginally quieter; Quetzal marginally more central. Don't overthink it.

Are Quetzal/Tucan too old and dated?

They're established, not dated. Some areas show age, but the mature landscaping and wildlife integration create character that new resorts can't match. If you need ultra-modern facilities, try Iberostar Paraíso. If you appreciate natural atmosphere, these deliver.

How do these compare to the bigger Iberostar Paraíso complex?

Paraíso is newer, larger, with more amenities (waterpark, golf). Quetzal/Tucan are older, smaller, with more natural character and wildlife. Paraíso feels like a mega-resort; Quetzal/Tucan feel like tropical hotels. Different appeals.

Is the wildlife safe around children?

Generally yes, with supervision. Don't let children feed or chase animals. Coatis can bite if people feed them (don't). Peacocks and iguanas are harmless. The wildlife is a highlight for most families—kids love it.
